But how can citizens share a common life and strive for the common good when the rich are so much better than everyone else (just ask them!) As long as a significant segment of the population believes that personal wealth and human worth are the same thing, we will continue to talk past each other about issues that truly matter (e.g. real equality of opportunity rather than paying lip service to the same, how to finance public goods equitably, caring about and for people who hit a rough spot through no fault of their own, etc).

But I'm not as pessimistic as you are. Elections are always just around the corner and Democrats must start nominating and supporting candidates who are not just Republican-lite. Those candidates must find their voice and not be afraid to speak the truth. When one party so clearly supports the narrow interests of a thin sliver of the country, forming a winning coalition of everyone else shouldn't be rocket science.

I have read this piece and most of the comments on it, and still do not have a good grasp on what should be done. Certainly workers should have the retirement funds they were promised, but where are the funds coming from? Is it from the banks? Is it from the government (think us)? Is the Detroit situation just the natural evolution of having a competitive system with few checks and balances so as to exclude all Americans, or is it an anomaly? Will the 1% or 5 % of us ever buy into the trickle down model so as to stop this insane wealth divide model that we live in?
Will we continue to choose to pursue strategies of "me first" instead of "our world first". Is there any evidence that people, read nations, act in ways other than their narrow short term interests?
I suspect I know the answers to these questions and I am not optimistic.

There are many unintended or unexpected consequences to Obamacare that, at least in the short term, provide less health insurance to people of limited means. As an example, in the run up to the January 1 start of insurance coverage, people of limited means can no longer (since July 1st) get Healthy NY insurance - leaving a six month gap in coverage of affordable insurance. I am also told by healthcare professionals that it has become difficult for poor patients to get medial appliances (like wheelchairs) repaired because there is now one low bid contractor for the whole state.

No doubt other glitches will occur but the jury is still out whether it will work and whether it will be cost effective. .Too many people commenting here have a philosophical belief in Obamacare but no deep understanding of the difficulties the poor have in getting healthcare or in the complexity of this program. I'm pulling for it to work but have my doubts.

There may be a place for payday lenders, but the high interest rates charged are not driven by high default rates. I have done the analysis and default rates are lower than most credit card companies. If costs are higher, it is primarily due to lenders having so many storefronts, but that shouldn't be an issue for online lenders. The rates charged are typically the maximum permitted on a state-to-state basis. Lenders argue that high default rates drive interest rates, but in fact, it is only high demand for short-term loans.

What I meant by martingale method in Hans #15 was something analogous to the one dimensional case. There, for initial position 0, set the probability of first exiting at position $x$ be $p_x$. Then for $x > 0$ and $y > 0$, $xp(x)-yp(-y)=0$ and $p(x)+p(-y)=1$. So $p(x)=\frac{y}{x+y}$. This is much simpler than solving a difference equation.

In 2 dimension, $(x,y)$ is a martingale function. However, integration around the exiting boundary does not give a direct solution to the exit probability. Does any one have any insight for finding an appropriate martingale function that does the job?

We're not going to make much progress on a housing finance policy unless we remember that the FanFred/FHA/VA system was originally a response to a housing shortage. When WWII ended, 68 years ago this month, the population was 150 million and the housing deficit was 6 million units. Rosie the Riveter and GI Joe got married in their millions with nowhere to live. Construction boomed and thrifts, with the backstop of the Federal Home Loan Banks and the GSEs provided the financing. This worked well during the 50s but began to fall apart during the Great Inflation of the 70s. Money market funds killed the thrifts, whose advantage of paying interest on balances was lost, with some leaping into the flames of the FSLIC disaster.

In the meantime, however, the national housing shortage became a surplus, albeit one that did not comport well with white flight. By the end of the 90s, cheap money and seemingly endless property appreciation cemented the idea "my home is my ATM."

The multiple causes of the burst included a chain of incentives where seemingly everyone made money off the same transaction and up front. This took us very far away from the original White Picket Fence.

The successors to the GSEs should do purchase money and rate/term refi loans for primary residents, exclusively. Investor and cash-out refi loans should be left to the mercies of the marketplace.

Or, we should simply rethink the imperative of "owning" one's own home.

Even so I can't see Millers earning more than $20 million maximum for weekend #2 and it can only go down from there. Yes I can see your point. Indeed it would be great to die of a rusty nail scratch because vaccine wouldn't have been found in our mudhuts.
Are you not taking advantage of any progress of medicine as let's say aspirin, antibiotics, contact lenses? Would you really want to live in a house without running water, electricity and toilets?
Don't you think you're mixing everything up?

Cookie, you miss the point because you think: would I want to live my life as I know it now but in a house without running water, electricity and toilets? You think: would I want to live my life as I know it now dying of a rusty nail scratch?

But, it's a failure of imagination. Imagine that your life feels magnificent, grand and joined with a knowledge of nature. There are no such things as houses and running water and toilets and electricity... not even nails.

There's no reason to think that if you die, you are dying in a stupid and unnecessary way because everything seems not stupid and absolutely necessary.

That when you die, for whatever reason, it just doesn't feel small and stupid at all, because in no way can your life ever seem small and stupid.

We have cut ourselves off from even imagining with force such a reality.

Even as I am typing this... thinking this... I know I cannot truly imagine it in full. I can imagine it just a little bit. And, it's just a shadow of an idea.

It's a shame.

That most neuroscience is work apart from and distant from the entirety of the person, his body, his economic and social circumstance, his history, is a natural progression of the the reductionist mindset we've been saddled with for the past few hundred years. A mindset observed most clearly in what they call Free Market Capitalism in the economic arena--everything can be reduced to be owned.

Those who leave life for the laboratory, never bothering to step outside the hermetically sealed box and witness what a natural consequence looks like in chaotic, sublimely rich nature, they are driving the destruction of earth. For, though we would be in mudhuts, yes, we would not be facing potential extinction consequent to climate change if the scientists who now and in the past contrive to make life more efficient and more profitable had never entered the laboratory.

I am a long-time observer of this phenomenon, both as a pedestrian and as a driver in the Washington area.. I have no doubt that BMW drivers are afflicted with a smug and false sense of entitlement.

I have even been berated and belittled by a BMW-owning neighbor for not owning a BMW myself. Lexus SUV's, whether driven by men or women, are in the same category, but not quite at the BMW level, I perceive. Makes a person wish they could all be stripped and flogged in the public square while firemen watch the public torch their cars.

BTW, I could likely write a check for any BMW or Lexus that I know of, but owning a couple of Toyotas and a Subaru keeps me grounded in the ordinances of politesse and common sense. The only reason to buy a BMW or similar is that it is not enough for some people to have money (or good credit); their egos demand that they advertise the fact. My question for them is, if you're so rich, why aren't you smart?

In my circle there are many people who could drive BMW's or Lexuses but who prefer to stick to less ostentations cars to avoid being grouped with the stereotypical BMW or Lexus a-holes.

As for the Prius, I drive a Prius in Maryland, where the car is considered to be an economy car, not a status symbol--fleet cars and taxis, e.g.-- and I just don't see Prius owners driving smugly in the way that BMW drivers do. I think that I lack the inferiority complex that causes people to try to prove that god made them superior.

I have long conducted a personal survey of asinine driving acts by make of car. It is staggering the frequency with which the perpetrator of such an act is behind the wheel of a BMW. In my survey, conducted all along the east coast, though mostly in the north-east, roughly 50% of rude and reckless behavior on the highway is by BMW drivers - even though BMW has only 2% overall market share! By comparison, Mercedes drivers - though almost as common (by market share), exhibit less than one tenth the bad behavior of the BMW drivers (at least in my presence).
You'd be safer ground considering them misguided jerks.
If you knew cars at all, you'd never have included Jaguar with Bentleys and Rolls.

If you ever drove a VW Beatle, you quickly learned that a BMW, Mercedes, Cadillac, etc. was going to cut you off or tailgate you if you had the audacity to be in front.  I learned that not allowing them to intimidate me would would seriously agitate the driver, with horn blowing, obscenities screamed, and aggressive driving sometimes resulting in their being stopped by police. I totally enjoyed tooting the horn and waving cheerfully at them at the side of the road.
